questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding elements of primary healthcare are true: 1. It includes education concerning health problems and methods of preventing them. 2. It involves the promotion of food supply and appropriate nutrition. 3. It provides essential and non-essential drugs. 4. It consists of individuals who have a common health goal based on community requirements. 5. It emphasizes maternal and child health care, including family planning.
Which primary healthcare principle is represented by the displayed image to ensure appropriate usability and quality?
questions.explanation:
Equitable distribution (Option D):
  • Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status.

Intersectoral coordination (Option C):
  • Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc.
  • Maintains good health.

Appropriate technology (Option A):
  • Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community
  • Eg:
    • ORS
    • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label
    • Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading
    • Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care

Community participation (Option B):
  • Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining.
  • For the promotion and maintenance of their health.
  • Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community.

questions.text: Which of the following responsibilities is NOT part of the ASHA worker's role in the community?

options.label: A
options.text: Promoting health and sanitation practices in the village.

options.label: B
options.text: Providing first-aid and medical care for minor ailments like diarrhea and fever.

options.label: C
options.text: Administering immunizations directly to children and pregnant women.

options.label: D
options.text: Serving as a depot holder for essential medications like oral rehydration salts and iron tablets.

questions.correct_answer: C. Administering immunizations directly to children and pregnant women.
questions.explanation:
ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  1. Promote health and sanitation practices.
  2. Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  3. Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  4. Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  5. Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  6. Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes their primary functions and focus areas of Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHCs) ?

options.label: A
options.text: UPHCs manage all aspects of secondary and tertiary care within the centre itself, including complex surgeries and specialized treatments.

options.label: B
options.text: UPHCs provide preventive and primary healthcare services, including immunization, maternal health, and management of common illnesses, while also implementing national health programs and engaging with the community.

options.label: C
options.text: UPHCs are involved in managing and screening for non-communicable diseases like diabetes and hypertension, providing initial care and follow-up, and referring patients to higher-level facilities .

options.label: D
options.text: UPHCs collaborate with NGOs and the private sector to enhance community health and environmental initiatives.

questions.correct_answer: B. UPHCs provide preventive and primary healthcare services, including immunization, maternal health, and management of common illnesses, while also implementing national health programs and engaging with the community.
questions.explanation:
Primary Healthcare Provision
  • Urban healthcare delivery focuses on primary healthcare, addressing both preventive and curative services for urban populations, particularly the underserved.

Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHCs)
  • UPHCs provide essential services such as immunization, maternal and child health (MCH), family planning, and management of common illnesses.

Special Focus on Slum Populations
  • Urban health programs prioritize the health needs of slum dwellers, addressing challenges like inadequate sanitation, overcrowding, malnutrition, and poor access to medical care.

Referral Services
  • UPHCs function as referral units for secondary or tertiary hospitals when specialized care or inpatient services are needed. They offer first-contact care and are key to urban referral chains.

Health Education and Awareness
  • UPHCs actively promote health education
  • Focusing on hygiene, nutrition, sanitation
  • Prevention of communicable and non-communicable diseases.

Implementation of National Health Programs
  • Urban health units implement national health programs such as the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP), malaria control programs, and the National Health Mission.

Sanitation and Environmental Health Initiatives
  • UPHCs, in collaboration with municipal bodies, support environmental health initiatives, including sanitation drives, solid waste management, and vector control programs.

School Health Programs
  • School health services include regular health check-ups, screening for nutritional deficiencies, oral health, and promotion of healthy lifestyle habits among students.

Adolescent Health Services
  • UPHCs provide specialized services for adolescents, focusing on reproductive health, mental health, substance abuse prevention, and nutrition, as part of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

Community Outreach
  • Health outreach workers, such as ASHAs and ANMs, facilitate direct community engagement, promoting access to services, immunizations, maternal health, and follow-up care in urban areas.

Collaboration with NGOs and Private Sector
  • Urban health initiatives often involve partnerships with non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the private sector to improve healthcare delivery, especially in underserved or densely populated urban areas.

Management of Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs)
  • UPHCs play a pivotal role in screening, early detection, and management of non-communicable diseases such as hypertension, diabetes, and heart diseases.
